About me
I am a currently an individual Postdoc at sDiv, the Synthesis center of the German Center for Integrative Biodiversity Research (iDiv) Halle-Jena-Leipzig.
I am generally interested in population biology, which I have studied from the context of Ecology, Genetic and Conservation.
During my PhD research I was focusing on the genetic monitoring of Chimpanzee and Gorilla population. I collected and analyzed non-invasive genetic samples (i.e., poop samples) to estimate population size and growth of focal populations.
After an extensive career break (due to a vortex of department closure, maternity, Covid-19 and second maternity), I stepped back into research with the ambition to reconnect to population processes at a larger scale. My current project at sDiv makes use of publicly available microsatellite genotypes of vertebrates to investigate worldwide patterns in genetic diversity, across Latitudes and life-history strategies.





Building this website
This website was built using Quarto.

title: My CV
text:
Individual Post-Doctoral Position, sDiv Synthesis Center, German Center for intergrative Biodiversity Research (iDiv) Halle-Jena-Leipzig. Project title: “Unraveling the relationship between genetic diversity, the latitudinal gradient in biodiversity, and life-history strategies”. Supervision: Chloé Schmidt, Michael Gerth, Jonathan Chase.





Career Break & Maternity





Doctoral Student, Molecular Genetic Lab (led by Linda Vigilant) and Gorilla Behavioral Ecology Group (led by Martha Robbins), Department of Primatology, Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology. “Genetic population monitoring of African great apes”.





Volunteer field research assistant (Gabon). MPI-EVA. Led by Prof. Dr. Christophe Boesch and Dr. Martha Robbins





Research Assistant, Molecular Genetic Lab (led by Linda Vigilant)
